awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: DYNAMICS OF DENSITIES: MODELING, CONTROL AND ESTIMATION
awd_abstract_narration:
Present day advances in guidance and control, from aerospace applications to modern device technologies, require ever more sophisticated ways to deal with the deluge of data and to cope with the probabilistic nature of uncertainty. The proposed research aims at developing novel computational techniques and new mathematics that address problems in decision and control of uncertain systems and in regulating collections of dynamical systems in a unified manner. Typical examples include the steering of collections of dynamical systems such as a collection of unmanned area vehicles, a particle beam, micro-mechanical systems subject to thermal fluctuations, laser-driven molecular reactions, or the scheduling and control of the flow of resources across a network. Multiple engineering and scientific disciplines stand to gain from successful completion of the project.

The basis of the proposed framework is the newly discovered Riemannian structure of Optimal Mass Transport (OMT) on probability densities. The ensuing geometry allows new techniques for the analysis of stochastic differential equations, a new perspective of collective dynamics of particles that leads to new modeling principles, and leads to a unified approach for designing suitable control laws that ensure stability and performance of collections of dynamical systems. Density functions become the primary object of study as these represent the state of the collection of dynamical systems. Data provide empirical snapshots, statistics, and histograms viewed as points on the Riemannian manifold of density functions. The description of system-states and uncertainty via density functions is compatible with novel mathematical concepts and tools in partial differential equations that can be now used for control purposes. This new viewpoint transcends control applications and may impact non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, medical imaging, filtering and signal analysis. The mathematics that we will develop aim to extend the current framework OMT to address multi-dimensional objects and tensor fields and, thereby, applications in diffusion tensor imaging, stochastically driven density flows of interacting dynamical particles, and network transport applications will be a focus of the research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of the project has been a seemingly old problem, how to model, assess, and regulate (stochastic) uncertainty. The central object of study has been a probability density that quantifies uncertainty but also the distribution of physical entities (mass, charge, resources, and so on). The research established a novel framework that builds on and expands recently developed links between the theory of optimal mass transport (OMT), stochastic control, optimal estimation, and optimization. Specifically, the framework focuses on density flows and provides useful insights and tools to deal with underlying dynamics and how to regulate such. 

The intellectual merit stems from the fact that the conceptual framework of viewing densities as a primary object, and seeking dynamics to fit empirical data or to meet desired control specifications, is a paradigm shift. The mathematics for formulating related problems via the theory of OMT has recently come into focus and is fast developing with implications that transcend control, reaching into non-equilibrium statistical mechanics, medical imaging, filtering and signal analysis. The broader impact includes anticipated technological advances that can be built with the theoretical and computational tools developed in guidance and control of uncertain systems (e.g., in aerospace applications), regulating devices affected by thermal fluctuations (including high resolution measuring instruments), financial (in distribution of resources), and modern device technologies. Review articles have been written (SIAM Review, Control Systems Magazine, Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems) to disseminate the new theories and advances. In addition, the project has created research opportunities for undergraduate students and resulted in multiple workshops in the control and applied math communities to engage broader audiences. 

The project accomplished several complementing goals, chief among those have been transformative new tools that allow regulation of systems that are subject to thermal excitation. These constitute advances in the emerging field of finite-time thermodynamics. Specifically, utilizing the theory of OMT and stochastic control, the project produced optimal protocols for regulating stochastic thermodynamic engines to achieve maximal power and optimal efficiency under different conditions in thermal excitations (temperature variation). Bounds on power and efficiency, and fundamental limits of what can be achieved, have been produced for heat engines in contact with varying temperature heat baths as well as for engines that are simultaneously in contact with multiple heat baths, akin to anisotropy in thermal or chemical potential that is common in the biological world of molecular machines.

A link between information and power in stochastic models of engines has been explored that yielded new insights into non-equilibrium thermodynamics. Specifically, this line of research of the project yielded results that quantify the tightness of the second law of thermodynamics for systems regulated by feedback utilizing continuous-time measurements.

On the computational side, challenging optimization problems have been tackled. First, a rather effectively scaled framework for solving multi-marginal OMT problems based on probabilistic graphical models has been developed; this framework is enabling for a variety of estimation and machine learning applications. Second, a natural formulation of unbalanced OMT problems, once again of great importance in machine learning applications, has been put forth and solved; in this excess mass is dispensed in a probabilistic sense whereupon the solution satisfies a maximum likelihood principle.

The project led to new mathematical results on topics of foundational importance in stochastic control and machine learning -- OMT and Schroedinger bridges, both in continuous-time and space as well as in discrete. The latter results impact dynamics, modeling and control over networks. Two lines of research that were especially notable are a stability theory of stochastic models in opinion dynamics, and a novel concept of circulation and pertinent geometry of flow fields in graphs.

The scope of the project, uncertainty control, whether for stochastic thermodynamic system and stochastic engines, opinion models, or density flows for collectives of particles, generated new tools and concepts (Schroedinger bridges with losses, geometry of anisotropically driven stochastic flows, multi-marginal OMT and graphical models). These theoretical and computational tools are expected to impact applications beyond those studied during the project. As a concrete example, on the topic of thermodynamic engines that help model molecular machines, the project produced control protocols for optimally driving gyrating engines and ways to make these autonomous. As displayed in Figure 1 (publication in arXiv and Physical Review Resesarch), the prototype where circulating current powered by Nyquist-Johnson thermal noise in two unequal-temperature resistors provides a proof-of-concept for a seemingly "three-piston" (constituted in sliding dielectric padding) engine activated by the circulating current.
